69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:55): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c_: <font> and style="" are "low quality" because they are media-specific, and potentially hide information from non-presentational UAs.

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:56): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c_: <div>s-containing-inlines are "low quality" because they imply some sort of paragraphing structure without giving any information about why
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:57): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c_: (typically, the latter is used as a workaround for the lack of a widget abstraction language like xbl)
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (01:57): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: I don't see how style="" is media-specific
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (01:58): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: it lacks the ability to give different styles per media, but can still be used in media-independent ways
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (01:58): since in practice most styles are not media-scoped anyway, nor do they need to be
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:59): ok, strike the media-specific part
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (01:59): in that case, style="" hides no more information than <style>, <link rel="stylesheet"> or <style scoped>
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:59): (though i actually do believe they usually result in media-specific content, even if it's technically possible to use them otherwise)
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (01:59): none of which you have labelled "low quality"
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:00): I have to go grab a beer, brb

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:00): i considered including <style>, but in practice if you use a style sheet with selectors you tend to be pushed towards content that can stand even without the stylesheet.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:01): obviously though that's not automatically the case, which is why the other mode wouldn't be called "high quality"
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:06): if you include <style> and <link rel="stylesheet"> it would make it pretty hard to have a useful non-low-quality document
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:06): indeed
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:07): but I don't think there's any evidence of a difference in hiding information from non-presentational UAs between those and style=""
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:07): oh come now
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:07): I mean, that might be the case, but I am not sure how you would quantify it
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:08): oh i don't know that it could be quantified
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:09): is there any way to show evidence for or against?

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:09): but it certainly is clear to me that you can improve the quality of almost any document with <font>, style="", or <div>s-containing-inlines, whereas i don't think the same can be said of all documents that do not have those characteristics.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:09): objectively? i don't know
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:09): i haven't looked at it in detail
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:10): obviously it's hard to argue against your proposal if it is based on an an unfalsifiable claim
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:11): it's not really a proposal
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:11): just an idea
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:11): i don't think we can drop style="", <font>, and <div>s-containing-inlines altogether
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:11): ok, s/proposal/idea/
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:11): but i do think that we should discourage their use in favour of the alternatives

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (02:11): Could call it "Compatibility" instead of "Low quality", and have it provide the features that are compatible with implementations and content and forbid things that are likely to cause authors pain and not attempt to make subjective judgements of value
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:11): dropping all those would certainly make a lot of documents nonconforming for seemingly-gratuitous reasons

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:12): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: it's not really compatibility either, since if we were desigining the language from scratch, you'd still want these features
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:12): I just don't see any reason to discourage style="" if <style scoped> won't be similarly discouraged
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:12): the latter can be abused in all the same ways, the main difference is that it is more verbose

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:13): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c: i'm not even talking about legacy content, even for a brand new language with no content i think these features are necessary, e.g. for prototyping
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:13): and less compatible with compatible with existing UAs
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:13): nor am i talking about abuse
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:13): you can abuse <ins> and <del>
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:13): and anything else
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:13): i'm talking about completely conforming and correct uses
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:13): ok, let me put it this way
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:13): I don't think systematically replacing all style="" with <style scoped> would improve any documents
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:13): i agree
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:14): it's a case-by-case problem
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:14): sometimes style="" has to be replaced with samething else, e.g. using a different element altogether
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:14): thus, creating an incentive to do so (badge-seeking behavior, etc) seems like a bad idea
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:15): granted, but it seems better than giving the impression that a page that uses only <div>s and style="" is fine.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:16): bbl
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:24): I agree such documents are not great; just not sure how to make a good machine-checkable rule that detects bad style
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:48): yeah

73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (03:00): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: i think having different conformance levels is a bad idea. we should just allow style="" and <div>s containing inlines but perhaps discourage the former for authors
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:02): how?
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (03:03): by saying that they are conforming, and then having a note about why style="" can be harmful

73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (03:04): this way, badge hunters won't replace their style=""s with more verbose but no better alternatives, and people can cite the spec about why people shouldn't use style=""
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (03:05): (i don't think <div>s containing inlines is harmful)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:07): there are pages that consist of nothing but <div>s and style=""s
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:07): or even just <div>s and stylesheets
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (03:08): indeed

73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (03:09): they are not going to disappear if we label them non-conforming, but some might be rewritten to use constructs that pass validation without increasing the quality or semantics
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (03:10): i don't think labeling them non-conforming will result in them being rewritten to use semantic markup

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:12): it might not affect _those_ pages, but i think it would help with people the same way that having "strict" vs "transitional" has helped some in terms of mindshare growth
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (03:13): hmm, perhaps
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (03:15): That seems to resulted in people choosing to use transitional twenty times more often than strict
